speaker: David Jordan
words: This is February the 25th, 1982, Stuart Yeager conducting an interview with Edith Renfrow Smith.

speaker: Yeager
words: I just wanted to ask you -- The very first question is:  Is Anna May Lucas still living?

speaker: Smith
words: Yes, she is.

speaker: Yeager
words: Oh, where is she living?

speaker: Smith
words: In Stockton, California.

speaker: Jordan
words: Do you have her address?

speaker: Smith
words: I have it -- but she is not competent. And her name is Anna May Boyden now.

speaker: Jordan
words: How do you spell that?

speaker: Smith
words: B-O-Y-D-E-N. But her husband would be very helpful. His name is Howard Boyden. She is in a nursing home.“Howard Boyden“

speaker: Yeager
words: That's too bad.

speaker: Smith
words: Yes. And if you had talked to her last summer, she would have been fine, but just this past fall,, she's had to go in the nursing home. And, of course, it all depends. It's like all older people. She has her good days and bad days. So, if you get her -- and any questions you might have, you might give them to her husband and he would be able to secure the information for you on her good day.

speaker: Yeager
words: O.K. She lives in Stockton, California. Is that near San Francisco by any chance?

speaker: Smith
words: It's about fifty miles.

speaker: Jordan
words: Stuart was in San Francisco last weekend.

speaker: Smith
words: Oh, I see. Well, that would have been a -- I hadn't been out here last week so... Because you could have called him. It was close enough.

speaker: Yeager
words: I would have gone down there. I wanted to ask you first off a couple of questions about your mother before we get to your own experience. Your mother's name was...

speaker: Smith
words: Eva Pearl Craig.

speaker: Yeager
words: Eva Pearl Craig. Do you have any idea whether -- when she went to this Grinnell Academy.

speaker: Smith
words: Well, if you can check back on Grace Parsons, who was a classmate of hers --

speaker: Jordan
words: Parsons?

speaker: Smith
words: Yes, Grace Parsons. Grace Parsons Peck.

speaker: Laura Wieman
words: Mrs. Paul Peck.

speaker: Yeager
words: They went the same year?

speaker: Smith
words: Yes.

speaker: Yeager
words: O.K. Did she graduate?

speaker: Smith
words: No.

speaker: Yeager
words: She went --

speaker: Smith
words: I don't know how long.

speaker: Yeager
words: You don't know how long.

speaker: Smith
words: No, I don't know how long.

speaker: Yeager
words: O.K.

speaker: Jordan
words: Do you know if others of the black community in Grinnell went to the academy?

speaker: Smith
words: Well, as far as I know, there weren't that many here then. Because my mother has never spoken of them. So if they lived here, she didn't know about it. So I don't think. they --

speaker: Wieman
words: None of her relatives went?

speaker: Smith
words: Well, Uncle John, who was Anna May's father. You know, she was here living with them over on West Street. That was when the triplets were born.

speaker: Yeager
words: So, as far as you know, Anna May Lucas was the only other black?

speaker: Smith
words: No.

speaker: Yeager
words: Well, in your family anyways, or in the town of Grinnell, to come to Grinnell.

speaker: Smith
words: Yes, she's the only one. I'm sure she was the only one.

speaker: Yeager
words: Do you know why Anna May did not stay at Grinnell?

speaker: Smith
words: She decided to take up nursing. And she went to Kansas City.

speaker: Yeager
words: You talked in your interview about a man from Zululand.

speaker: Smith
words: Yes.

speaker: Yeager
words: Couldn't find him anywhere.

speaker: Smith
words: I don't understand that.

speaker: Yeager
words: Couldn't locate his name.

speaker: Smith
words: His last name was Sedweyo.

speaker: Yeager
words: You don't happen to know how that was spelled?

speaker: Smith
words: I've heard half a dozen --- but he was from Zululand.

speaker: Wieman
words: What year was that, Edith?

speaker: Smith
words: Well, he was here at the same time the -- Campbell, --

speaker: Jordan
words: Mona Chie?

speaker: Smith
words: He came at the same time as Mona Chie. Mona Chie died and he stayed. He finished out the year. Now, whether he came back the next year, I don't know. But, see, Mona Chie died of pneumonia. Do you have a record of Mona Chie?

speaker: Yeager
words: Yes. I have --

speaker: Smith
words: Well, then, Blamos Sedweyo was -

speaker: Jordan
words: Do you have any idea of the spelling?

speaker: Wieman
words: Well, if you looked in that class register and there was a very foreign sounding name --

speaker: Smith
words: I have that in a book that he signed at our house and I don't know where -- I hope I can find it. It's an old book that mother had and I haven't looked at that book for years.

speaker: Yeager
words: Did all the Grinnell students sign that book?

speaker: Smith
words: No, no. He just happened to sign it because -- Oh, he did the caligraphy, so that was why it was so outstanding, because I write so terrible.

speaker: Yeager
words: Do you know anything else about him?

speaker: Smith
words: That's all.

speaker: Yeager
words: That's all you know. And do you think he was one of the Rosenwald scholars?

speaker: Smith
words: I think so. I'm sure he was, because I think all of them came here at the same time. Hosea Campbell and ---

speaker: Yeager
words: Did Hosea Campbell come to your home?

speaker: Smith
words: Oh, yes, See, all of those fellows --- the reason I know about them is because I was just a little girl and they came to the house on Sunday afternoons and my sister played the piano and they would sing and Mom always had something for them.

speaker: Yeager
words: So you wouldn't be able to recall anything specific about any of these people other than their names, probably.

speaker: Smith
words: Nothing other than the name. And then one of the fellows was my sister's boy friend.

speaker: Yeager
words: And that was Gordon?

speaker: Smith
words: No, no.

speaker: Yeager
words: That wasn't Gordon.

speaker: Smith
words: No, Gordon Kitchen was Anna May's boy friend. Siebert Dove. He taught at Prairie View.

speaker: Yeager
words: Right. And he's past away, right?

speaker: Smith
words: Yes.

speaker: Yeager
words: You have no idea, anything about Alphonse Henningburg?

speaker: Smith
words: Well, he's still living.

speaker: Yeager
words: He is?

speaker: Smith
words: Yeah. And --

speaker: Jordan
words: No, he's not living now.

speaker: Smith
words: He's not living now? Well, when did he die?

speaker: Yeager
words: I have no record of him. He's lost.

speaker: Jordan
words: I was thinking of Hightower. Kealing, tall. He died last year.

speaker: Smith
words: Yes. But as far as I know Alphonse is still living.

speaker: Yeager
words: Do you have any idea where he's living?

speaker: Smith
words: Well, I could ask my sister because --- the last time, I think, she said he was living in New York. Now, I'm not sure.

speaker: Yeager
words: In the city?

speaker: Smith
words: In the city of New York. But I can find out. One of my two sisters knows where.

speaker: Yeager
words: He used to live around Hempstead, New York, and I called the directory assistance around that area and they had no Henningburg listed so I was wondering.

speaker: Smith
words: Well, I'll ask her because she'll probably know because she keeps tabs with lots of people.

speaker: Yeager
words: Which sister is this?

speaker: Smith
words: This is my sister Alice. She's the one that finished from Hampton Institute.

speaker: Yeager
words: And is she living in Washington?

speaker: Smith
words: She lives in Forestville, Maryland. That's right out of ---

speaker: Yeager
words: I live in Maryland.

speaker: Smith
words: Oh, do you?

speaker: Yeager
words: Yeah.

speaker: Smith
words: Well, you know, it used to be Suitland and they changed the post office to Forestville. That's where she still lives.

speaker: Jordan
words: Do you know anything more about the Rosenwald Scholarship Program?

speaker: Smith
words: All I know is that they sent those boys here and paid their way.

speaker: Jordan
words: One of the reasons we ask
tags: The first group did not appear to have the direct connection with Tuskegee, but the group that came in the 1920's, three of them came from Tuskegee.

speaker: Smith
words: Yes, but see those, I think, you see, Mona Chie and Blamos Sedweyo, they were Africans and they wouldn't have any direct connection with---. And, I think, it was only later that Rosenwald was in touch with Tuskegee.

speaker: Yeager
words: Now, Siebert Dove lived with the Steiners.

speaker: Smith
words: Yes.

speaker: Yeager
words: What kind of a connection was there between Steiner and Dove?

speaker: Smith
words: Probably none. Only thing, he spoke French fluently and they were very literate and they probably were --- they were liberal. And they were happy to have him. Because at that time Grinnell was not a liberal town at all. There were many well, it was just like living in the South almost in some places -- because, they couldn't go up to the movie. They had to sit up -if you went to the movie, you had to sit upstairs.

speaker: Yeager
words: And the restaurants were very restricted

speaker: Smith
words: Well, who went to the restaurants? No one could afford to go to restaurants so we really didn't --- that didn't enter into it. But, I mean things like --- and then we had the Candyland. And of course we weren't allowed in the Candyland.

speaker: Wieman
words: Where did the other fellows live?

speaker: Smith
words: Oh, they lived on campus. And I don't know why Siebert Dove lived there with the Steiners.

speaker: Yeager
words: They all seemed to live in Smith. A popular hall. Did you know Clifton Lamb?

speaker: Smith
words: Yes.

speaker: Yeager
words: I was just curious. He is living in Maryland and I'm going to be seeing him over the vacation.

speaker: Smith
words: Did you know we always considered him more Indian than anything else.

speaker: Yeager
words: Why is that?

speaker: Smith
words: I don't know. I guess it's just because when I was a little girl we just thought he was an Indian.

speaker: Wieman
words: That's interesting ..

speaker: Smith
words: It was.

speaker: Yeager
words: Did he have contacts with your home also?

speaker: Smith
words: Oh, yes. I don't think any of them didn't come to the house.

speaker: Yeager
words: From when to when? From what period to what period?

speaker: Smith
words: All the time they were here. Because as long as my sisters were home they came. And of course Clifton Lamb, he spent a lot of time with Anna May. Because she was artistic and so was he.

speaker: Wieman
words: He wasn't part of the Rosenwald

speaker: Smith
words: He was a Rosenwald Scholar too.

speaker: Yeager
words: Can you tell me something about the Cosmopolitan Club since Anna May was very much involved in that. She traveled to Des Moines ---

speaker: Smith
words: Oh, well, don't ask me about that because I was too small.

speaker: Wieman
words: Have you talked to Rebecca French about that?

speaker: Yeager
words: No, I haven't. I'm going to.

speaker: Smith
words: Now, I think she would be a very good person to talk to.

speaker: Yeager
words: Can you tell me a little bit --- you talked on the tape about Professor Wittler and you mentioned that he had encouraged you to come to Grinnell.

speaker: Smith
words: Yes, because he told me that I could be a secretary if I came to Grinnell College.

speaker: Yeager
words: So, he offered you a job.

speaker: Smith
words: Well it was through the college. It wasn't outside the college. It was through the college that he said he would take me as his secretary.

speaker: Yeager
words: I see. So that enabled you to support yourself through school?

speaker: Smith
words: Well, it helped.

speaker: Yeager
words: It helped.

speaker: Smith
words: It helped. I mean, you can't, no, if my mother hadn't lived here, I wouldn't have been able to go to school, because, you see, I didn't have to pay any board and room.

speaker: Yeager
words: So you went home during the dinner hour.

speaker: Smith
words: Yes. Except when it was twenty-six below.

speaker: Yeager
words: I was wondering. So you weren't actively recruited by the college at all, other than just through this ---

speaker: Smith
words: Oh, no. Well, I mean, they didn't recruit me at all. I recruited myself because I --- see my other sisters had gone to --- one had gone to Ames and one had gone to Fisk. But I said I wasn't going to college unless I'd go to Grinnell College.

speaker: Yeager
words: Why was that?

speaker: Smith
words: Oh, I just loved it. And as long as I can remember we had been corning --- we always came up for the concerts and we came up for Vespers on Sunday afternoon. And Mrs. Conard was our Campfire leader and then I belonged to the Uncle Sam's Club which was a part of the social work that the college did and Rebecca came down and so really from as long as I can remember we had been associated with the college students and it always seemed like they were so interesting and they always did such great things. I recruited myself. And Professor Wittler just helped.

speaker: Yeager
words: So you did work for him after you got to Grinnell? And you worked as a secretary.

speaker: Smith
words: Oh, yes.

speaker: Yeager
words: Was that the whole four years?

speaker: Smith
words: And then I also worked over in the, oh, where they did the duplicating, you know.

speaker: Wieman
words: Oh, yes, service bureau, whatever it was called.

speaker: Smith
words: Well, whatever it was. It was in the administration building.

speaker: Wieman
words: Yeah. Thirty-five cents an hour.

speaker: Smith
words: Yeah. Well, it was good money.

speaker: Wieman
words: That's right. That was good money.

speaker: Smith
words: Yeah. That was great money.

speaker: Yeager
words: At that time, what type of occupational goals did you have? What were you planning on doing with your degree?

speaker: Smith
words: Oh, I was going to be a psychiatric social worker.

speaker: Yeager
words: When did you change your mind?

speaker: Smith
words: They changed it for me. were a senior, they took to people who would hire person who would hire me When, you know, back then, when you you to Chicago and introduced you you after graduation. Well, the only was the YWCA. You take what you get.

speaker: Yeager
words: Do you think that was because of race?

speaker: Smith
words: Yes, that was because of race. You see, one of the things that --- I don't know whether counselors didn't know any employers who would employ Negroes or whether they did. They probably didn't know any and there probably weren't that many who would. Because back there, you know, it was very difficult for you todo anything other than housework.

speaker: Yeager
words: Especially for a woman, I would think.

speaker: Smith
words: Yeah. Well, for men either. I mean, men, they didn't have that great an opportunity to do anything other than teach or be a mail carrier.

speaker: Yeager
words: I think that was the third or fourth black alumni that got involved in YMCA. Kitchen worked for the USO. And Redman worked for the YMCA for a period of time.

speaker: Smith
words: Yeah. Well, you see, when we have a limited horizon, you have to take the one that offers the --- and, see seventy-five dollars a month was a lot of money.in those days.

speaker: Yeager
words: What were your primary concerns as a student at college?

speaker: Smith
words: Meaning?

speaker: Yeager
words: Oh, academic, social, political.

speaker: Smith
words: No political.

speaker: Yeager
words: Nothing political.

speaker: Smith
words: No. Nothing political. I wasn't interested in politics in those days. We were just interested in having enough to eat.

speaker: Wieman
words: Brown went on a starvation diet. Don't you remember that?

speaker: Smith
words: Oh, yes. But he --- we always thought he was cracked. Cause, you know we always thought that he was very eccentric.

speaker: Wieman
words: He was.

speaker: Smith
words: And very strange. Fasting for what? You know.

speaker: Wieman
words: I can't remember now.

speaker: Smith
words: I don't remember either.

speaker: Wieman
words: Sorry I interrupted.

speaker: Jordan
words: What about extra-curricular activities?

speaker: Smith
words: Well, let me see. Whatever they had.

speaker: Wieman
words: I didn't have any in college. I couldn't get in the glee club.

speaker: Smith
words: Well, I did belong to the not the regular glee club, but you know the other one?

speaker: Wieman
words: No.

speaker: Smith
words: Well they had two. So, since I wasn't good enough for the first one, I ---

speaker: Wieman
words: I didn't even get in the second one.

speaker: Smith
words: Well, I did. We used to practise over in the Music Hall.

speaker: Wieman
words: Qh, for heaven's sakes.

speaker: Smith
words: And you know that Professor Pierce was very unhappy to have a black person in his choir. He almost died. Even though Anna May had worked for him. But Anna May was their maid so that was different.

speaker: Wieman
words: That was different.

speaker: Smith
words: That was a big difference.

speaker: Jordan
words: Did you find prejudice from the faculty? Or from the student body?

speaker: Smith
words: Well, you know, I think being a Negro you --- it just doesn't, you know --- . Now I knew that Professor Sherman didn't like Negroes. And I didn't think Professor Baurr.an liked them either. Neither one of them were important, so --- So you don't like me, so what? So, I mean, you know, that was the feeling. And all of the students that I came in contact with were very nice to me. So consequently I said I didn't --- I didn't get the feeling that so many people did of --- cause I feel that they're people just like anyone else if --- Some people you like and some people you don't like. So you have a right to your preference. So I said --- you know, that's why I ignored it. At least it didn't bother me. You see many people are bothered by it, but to me it doesn't bother me. ‚Ä¢

speaker: Yeager
words: What about some of the other students at Grinnell. Was it a a very negative or a positive reaction?

speaker: Smith
words: Well, they had, as far as I could see, they had a very positive reaction, and I was, you know, they tried to make the town students feel very at home and so we were affiliated with a cottage. I was affiliated with James. And, you know, we had the Colonial Ball in February. I had a very good time. We wore the costumes and what-have-you. And they did the Virginia reel and what-have-you, so -- at least, I didn't feel anything. Now, maybe other people did, but I didn't.

speaker: Yeager
words: O.K.

speaker: Smith
words: And I think that when you live in the town it's altogether different from coming into a city when you don't know the city. See, Grinnell was home.

speaker: Yeager
words: Yeah.

speaker: Smith
words: And so many of the people I associated with I had associated with all through school from the time I started. So it wasn't like coming into a community where you have to make new friends. Because most of the people I met when I came to Grinnell College I had known when I was in high school or before. And even the college students I had known because they had come to the club house, what they called Uncle Sam's Club.

speaker: Yeager
words: O.K. Did you have any contact with the blacks that came to Grinnell during World War II training?

speaker: Smith
words: No.

speaker: Yeager
words: You didn't have any ---- your family didn't have any contact with any of them?

speaker: Smith
words: Well, my mother did. But I wasn't home during World War II. I was gone. See in '37 I left.

speaker: Jordan
words: Did she ever speak much about that?

speaker: Smith
words: My mother?

speaker: Jordan
words: Yes.

speaker: Smith
words: She talked about them but, see, by that time Mother was old, much older.

speaker: Jordan
words: And there were no younger children at home.

speaker: Smith
words: There was no one there but her and if they came by she was very pleasant, but, you know, my house is quite a ways, unless they were going to the cemetery, they didn't pass it. And they no longer went to Arbor Lake. You see, we used to go to Arbor Lake and the students used to go to Arbor Lake and they'd come by the house and cut across the cow pasture going to the lake rather than go down West Street. But by that time Arbor Lake was no longer important. If they came they just walked down. I don't know how many students they had, colored students, they had then, if any, I don't know. I don't remember. I know that Alphanette White came up.

speaker: Yeager
words: Oh, yeah. Alphanette White. She ---

speaker: Smith
words: Now, Alphanette's mother was the Girl Reserve secretary when I went to the Y.  Alphanette was just a little girl then.

speaker: Yeager
words: Were you the only black student at Grinnell at that time?

speaker: Smith
words: Yes.

speaker: Yeager
words: We have another student, Ralph West.

speaker: Smith
words: If he was here, he didn't stay.

speaker: Yeager
words: O.K. So you didn't know each other. O.K. I was just curious. Did you discuss --- Now there was no NAACP in Grinnell, but several, I believe .1. of the alumni mentioned that there was some other organization that took the place of NAACP before it was formed in the late 50's and earlier there was no --- Uncle Sam's Club was the only social type organization.

speaker: Smith
words: Well, see, Uncle Sam's Club was for all the children who lived in that end of town. So it¬∑wasn't because we were black or anything else. It was just that it was in that end of town. And it was for those children who didn't have anything to do on Sunday afternoon and it gave those students who were going into social work, or whatever they were going into, an opportunity to work with young children. And that's what they did. And, you know, thay had the clubs. And I think that's why Mrs. Conard had the Blue Birds, the Girl Scouts, I mean not Girl Scouts, Campfire Girls.

speaker: Jordan
words: I gather from what you've said that as your generatifon came of age, your family and the Lucas famtly, people left Grinnell. And so the situation one finds as you go into the 1940's and the 1950's would be fewer and fewer black people ---

speaker: Smith
words: As they died out. They really didn't leave. They died out. They stayed here until they died.

speaker: Jordan
words: The parent generation. But you and your sisters, for example, left, and ---

speaker: Smith
words: Well, yeah, but the parent generation died. It wasn't that they moved away from Grinnell. I think that the only family -- Well, no Mrs. Tibbs died here. I think that most of the ones who had lived here died and then if there were any young ones they moved away. But other than that

speaker: Yeager
words: Was there any reason for that or just that they were pursuing a career?

speaker: Smith
words: Well, I mean, what they were doing, it wasn't that they were pursuing a career, they were pursuing a job. See, Grinnell was not a-~- At that time we had the glove factory. And after the glove factory we had the shoe factory. Well, the glove factory would hire no Negroes. And I don't know about the shoe factory because that came later. And I think my uncle was the only one who worked for the Spaulding Automobile.

speaker: Yeager
words: And that was John Lucas.

speaker: Smith
words: John Lucas.

speaker: Yeager
words: O.K. I was curious --- you mentioned in your piece about Alice not thinking that Grinnell was a very good place because of a lot of racism or snobbiness or whatever and that she went to Hampton because she thought it would be better.

speaker: Smith
words: Well, she went to Hampton because she could afford to go to Hampton. My brother had been there, and he was the one that was going to help her. Of course children in a family have different experiences. She was older. She had had a harder time than I did. The family was poorer when she came along. And so I'm sure that she got many more hard knocks than we did. Because I know that you know that in families the older ones try to shield the younger ones from the same sort of things that they had. I'm sure that they experienced many experiences that I didn't have.

speaker: Yeager
words: Can you tell me are any of the people who cooked at the college still living? Oscar Monroe?

speaker: Smith
words: Oscar Monroe is dead. Now whether Addie is dead, I do not know. Oscar's brother, George, may be still living in Kirksville, Missouri. I don't know.

speaker: Yeager
words: Oscar's brother?

speaker: Smith
words: George. He was a second cook.

speaker: Yeager
words: Kirksville?

speaker: Smith
words: Kirksville. That's just a little way over the border into Missouri. I don't know how far. But you know who used to keep in touch with Addie was Dick Ulrich.

speaker: Yeager
words: Dick Ulrich.

speaker: Jordan
words: He lives here in town.

speaker: Smith
words: He used to --- See, they used to play cards with them all the time. So he used to keep in touch with Addie. So I don't know whether he still does. And I don't know whether she's dead.

speaker: Yeager
words: O.K. Can you give me an idea of how many people in town, black people in town, worked for the college. I got some idea from the tape.

speaker: Smith
words: Well, my uncle worked at --- at the Quadrangle.

speaker: Yeager
words: Uncle John?

speaker: Smith
words: No. This was Uncle Saul. He was my Aunt Annie's husband and Aunt Annie was the --- had a hair dressing establishment downtown.

speaker: Yeager
words: Right. Transformations.

speaker: Smith
words: Yeah, she made transformations, but before then she had had a beauty parlor uptown on Broad Street in the block where Dr. Carney is now. In fact she was up the stairway with Dr. Brock who was a dentist.

speaker: Yeager
words: Now, Uncle Saul worked for --- was he one of the --

speaker: Smith
words: He was a cook, head cook, at the Quadrangle.

speaker: Yeager
words: And he's no longer living.

speaker: Smith
words: No. He died quite a while ago, about eight years ago I guess.

speaker: Yeager
words: If we'd only started this about ten years ago, we'd have a tremendous project.

speaker: Smith
words: That's the way a lot of us feel.

speaker: Yeager
words: For some, it's a little late. Now, is that the only other ---

speaker: Smith
words: Yes, he was the only one. Addie and Oscar and George worked at the men's dorm and Uncle Saul was over here.

speaker: Yeager
words: What about other administrative positions? No other positions?

speaker: Smith
words: No. Not any I know of. I never saw any up here.

speaker: Yeager
words: And a lot of people worked as domestics for professors then.

speaker: Smith
words: Yes. But there weren't that many to work as domestics because there weren't that many left in the town. I think Anna May worked for Professor Pierce because she was up here and my sister Evanel worked for the .Frisbies. They ran the newspaper. But she was in high school then.

speaker: Yeager
words: Evanel, is she .still living?

speaker: Smith
words: Oh, yeah.

speaker: Yeager
words: She's the youngest of the----

speaker: Smith
words: I'm the youngest. She's the next. And Alice is the next. That's the youngest, the next youngest and the next that are still living.

speaker: Yeager
words: And where is she living? Where is Evanel living?

speaker: Smith
words: Savannah, Georgia. She's the one that went to Ames.

speaker: Yeager
words: Clifton Lamb mentioned in his tape that he was thinking about either going to Grinnell or the University of Iowa and he said that the University of Iowa was very racist

speaker: Smith
words: It was. They were much --- Well, of course, Grinnell didn't consider itself racist anyway. Because, you know, this had ‚Ä¢ been an underground railroad city. And Grinnell had had a station, an underground railroad station. So on the foundation of this college, it shouldn't have been racist. So I'm sure that's something that he had on the back of his mind when he came. And the University of Iowa has --- well, when my sister moved to Iowa City they had no black students on campus at all. That's why she kept students. So it's only recently that they have allowed students to stay on campus.

speaker: Yeager
words: O.K. Can you tell me a little bit about your mother? Since she did go to the Grinnell Academy, she'd be one of the first women --- I think she'd probably be maybe the second

speaker: Smith
words: My mother was a lady before her time. My mother was a health fanatic before anyone was. We couldn't eat white bread. We had to eat oatmeal for breakfast and cornmeal mush. We had to eat no white bread at all. And everything she fixed was supposed to be --- you know, she talked about nutrition all the time. We couldn't eat tomatoes out of an aluminum pan because she used to say that she was sure they must cause cancer. In those days people thought aluminum was great. She said,"No aluminum. Anything that will take the color out of aluminum, it must take some of the metal out so you can't eat the stuff."And we couldn't have sweets, candy, no junk. And, you know, that was a person before her time.

speaker: Yeager
words: What did your mother do after she went to the academy? She went to the academy for just a year or so?

speaker: Smith
words: Yes. Then she went South to teach her cousin's children --as a governess to her cousin's children in Mound Bayou, Mississippi. And her cousin's husband was the first mayor of Mound Bayou.

speaker: Yeager
words: Did she ever talk about her experiences in Mississippi?

speaker: Smith
words: Nothing other than talking about the children that she took care of and about her ---

speaker: Yeager
words: Then she came back up.

speaker: Smith
words: Yes, then she came back here.

speaker: Jordan
words: Well, did she explain how she came about attending the academy.

speaker: Smith
words: Oh, no, school. she never said. She just said that she always loved Her sisters didn't like school and she did. And she said she always had her nose in a book. And then living with Uncle John, maybe that's why. I don't have any idea.

speaker: Wieman
words: Where had she gone to school?

speaker: Smith
words: She must have gone to school while she was with Uncle John.

speaker: Wieman
words: Right here in Grinnell.

speaker: Smith
words: And then in Oskaloosa before she came up here.

speaker: Wieman
words: Do you know how far she got?

speaker: Smith
words: No. I have no idea.

speaker: Yeager
words: O.K. So once your mother came back to Grinnell, did she stay at home and raise children?

speaker: Smith
words: No. She worked for Professor Franklin. Johnson. Franklin Johnson. She worked for Franklin Johnson. And I think that's the only one --- that's the only person I can remember. My mother was very active in church and with the WCTU and the missionary society. At that time we belonged to the Congregational --- my father was a Congregationalist so we belonged to the Congregational Church so I think that's one reason why she did that.

speaker: Jordan
words: Do you recall if in the years when you were growing up there were many speakers who came to the college or much attention that was ever given to the race question? I know that very early in the century, Professor Steiner brought W. E. B. Du

speaker: Smith
words: Bois to the campus but we haven't been able to tell what level of awareness there might have been or involvement with national issues --- Well, he was such an outstanding person that he was just a name that was talked about a lot in the house. I don't remember whether my mother came to the lecture or anything but that he was talked about a lot because they thought that he was such a wonderful person. And, of course, my father thought Marcus Garvey was the greatest. He talked about him a lot. But we were small and weren't aware of what was going on.

speaker: Yeager
words: What did your father do?

speaker: Smith
words: He was a chef.

speaker: Yeager
words: He was a chef. He wasn't a chef at the college?

speaker: Smith
words: He was a chef at the Monroe Hotel.

speaker: Yeager
words: The Monroe Hotel.

speaker: Jordan
words: We have some marvelous memoirs of Grinnell students who served tables and washed dishes and helped in the kitchen.

speaker: Smith
words: With Saul Brown?

speaker: Jordan
words: No, I'm talking about the Monroe Hotel.

speaker: Smith
words: Oh, at the Monroe Hotel.

speaker: Yeager
words: It's no longer ---

speaker: Smith
words: Oh, no, they have what they call the low housing for senior citizens.

speaker: Jordan
words: It was torn down in the early 7O's.

speaker: Smith
words: Yes. And that's where the underground railroad was.

speaker: Yeager
words: Oh. Was that whole story told to you by your parents?

speaker: Smith
words: What? The underground railroad?

speaker: Yeager
words: The underground railroad.

speaker: Smith
words: Oh, yes. And when they had --- Was that the Sesquicentennial we had?

speaker: Wieman
words: Yes.

speaker: Smith
words: My mother was in the pageant.

speaker: Wieman
words: They reenacted that.

speaker: Smith
words: And there should be a good write-up in the paper as well as some pictures.

speaker: Yeager
words: As a student at Grinnell, if you were the only black student in the whole school,--- you did live in town --- Did the students ask you a lot of questions about being black? Or was that not discussed at all?

speaker: Smith
words: Oh, no, they didn't. Well in the first place, I never knew I was black.

speaker: Yeager
words: Oh, really?

speaker: Smith
words: No, I didn't. That's what my husband always tells me now. He says,"You don't know you're black."Well, he does. He says,"You came up in the wrong environment. You don't think right. 11

speaker: Wieman
words: Well you did grow up in a unique situation.

speaker: Smith
words: I think it really was. And then too with my mother being the sort of person that she was. You know, she always taught us --- She said,"I don't care who it is, there is no one born any better than you are. They may have more money and they may be more beautiful. They may have outward things. But there's no one any better."So naturally if you're taught there's no one any better than you are, why you think you're pretty special. And so, I think that that made a great difference. I don't know whether she didn't talk that much to the other girls and my brother, or that my brother and I were just the youngest and she talked to us a lot. And then maybe she wasn't so harrassed. You know, when you only have --- there's six years between the next oldest and the last two, so you might have more time. And my mother was a great story teller. And I'm so sorry that we didn't have a tape recorder. She could quote Paul Laurence Dunbar and speak that dialect. It was beautiful! And no one --- I don't know anyone today --- who can speak it like she did. And she told us such great stories all the time. And she had a lot of information about her father's family and her mother's family that she told us. A..~d then, too, my mother, when she felt like it, she'd go and she'd play the piano. Well this was something that I don't think many children had that their mother would take the time to go and just bang on the piano because her kids wanted her to.

speaker: Jordan
words: You did say that you avoided someone like Professor Sherman or Professor Bauman.

speaker: Smith
words: I didn't avoid him. I just knew that he would rather not be bothered.

speaker: Jordan
words: So do you think that was, in the absence of any discussion even from students, something not talked about as much. Because we do find from interviews that Stuart has done with many of the blacks that were here later, the constant questioning and both honest curiosity and sometimes a matter of, it just seems, out of ignorance.

speaker: Smith
words: I don't know. I really have no idea because they never did. And the students, they came to my house. And they would have me come up to the college to stay and they wouldn't --- I mean, it was never as if you're a curiosity or you're different or anything like that. So that's why I say that I just never felt that they looked at me as though I was something different.

speaker: Yeager
words: What was the most positive and most negative experiences that you had at Grinnell as a student?

speaker: Smith
words: Well, I don't remember any negative experiences. I had all¬∑ positive ones as far as I can remember. Except that I felt that --- oh, I cannot think of the name of that English professor

speaker: Wieman
words: Woman?

speaker: Smith
words: Yes.

speaker: Wieman
words: Hunter?

speaker: Smith
words: Hunter. Edith Hunter. I told you her name was Edith Hunter.

speaker: Wieman
words: Grace.

speaker: Smith
words: Grace. Grace Hunter. You know, she's the one I told you used to go the cemetery to write. But now, when I was in her class, she would never give me anything but a C.

speaker: Yeager
words: Oh, really.

speaker: Smith
words: Yes. Nothing above a C. But I should say that one of the nicest experiences I had was when my economics professor - - - and that was Klerrrne ---

speaker: Wieman
words: ProfessorKlerrrne-.

speaker: Smith
words: Yes. I thought he was a great professor. Well, I liked economics anyway and I liked Professor Klemme.

speaker: Yeager
words: So you have no single positive experience that sticks out.

speaker: Smith
words: I just enjoyed my four years at Grinnell. I really did. I think it was one of the most pleasant times in my life. And I can't think of anything that --- nothing --- you know, no one --- I just have never felt that anyone thought I was important enough to go out of their way to be negative.

speaker: Yeager
words: To what degree were the issues of race discussed?

speaker: Smith
words: Never. Race never came up.

speaker: Yeager
words: Not in the class?

speaker: Smith
words: Not in the class. No one ever mentioned race. And to sort of point up the feeling of race --- well, I have two girls. Our little girl was seven years old and she came home from lab school one day and she said,"Momma, am I Chinese?"Now you could see what color I am. But, see, she never --- And the reason she asked that question was that they had been discussing Chinese at school. Not as far as color or anything, I don't think. But she just came home and asked if she were Chinese. I said,"No, you're not Chinese.Ii

speaker: Yeager
words: Was there anyone in your family --- I know it's very early in that period --- Was there anyone in the family who was --- you said your mother was before her time in certain respects --- Was there anyone in your family or in the town of Grinnell whom you would refer to as --- not a civil rights type person but someone who was very concerned about social issues.

speaker: Smith
words: I didn't know anybody.

speaker: Wieman
words: Mrs. Conard and Mr. Steiner.

speaker: Smith
words: Well, yes, but you know that wouldn't be anything ..

speaker: Wieman
words: They were college people.

speaker: Smith
words: They were college people and my association with Mrs. Conard was when she came --- with us when we went to camp and she came out and taught us about the stars. Of course, Rudy worked for Mrs. Conard. And that was the only time he ever got sick. She baked bananas for him.

speaker: Jordan
words: You told that story on the tape.

speaker: Smith
words: Yes. Oh, he felt awful. He didn't like bananas until the day he died.

speaker: Jordan
words: If I could ask you a question in relation to that
tags: How did you find other people responding to people like Professor Steiner or Mrs. Conard since they were outspoken people on these issues.

speaker: Smith
words: They may have been, but they were oustanding members of the community so consequently and --- weren't they Jewish?

speaker: Wieman
words: The Steiners were Jewish.

speaker: Smith
words: Yes. And I think that the Jewish people in the community had a much harder time than I did. At least from what I

speaker: Jordan
words: Well, of course, he had been raised Jewish, but he had converted at the time ---

speaker: Smith
words: Yes.

speaker: Wieman
words: But there were a few Jewish families in town.

speaker: Smith
words: Yes. We had the Bermans.

speaker: Wieman
words: And the Spectors.

speaker: Smith
words: Is he the one that had the shoe store?

speaker: Wieman
words: No, that was Bucksbaum.

speaker: Smith
words: Bucksbaum. But we really did have a cosmopolitan town because we had Joe Marcellino. You know, he always had those Italian --- Greek --- dinners out at his house. And he had all kinds of students c0.rne out there.

speaker: Yeager
words: Is Rudy still living.

speaker: Smith
words: No. He died.

speaker: Yeager
words: He has sons that

speaker: Smith
words: He has one son. And he'll be nineteen the seventeenth of May.

speaker: Yeager
words: His name is ---

speaker: Smith
words: Lee. Lee James.

speaker: Yeager
words: Does the name Collis Davis ring a bell?

speaker: Smith
words: Yes. He was another one that came to the house a lot. And then he was at Hampton when Rudy was there.

speaker: Yeager
words: I was going to ask about that. Was there some kind of a connection there. Did the family know ---

speaker: Smith
words: No. My mother sent Rudy to Hampton because she said he wouldn't be able to make a living unless he had a trade. He would have been a wonderful farmer. _But .he¬∑ was a brick-layer. And then after he had become a brick-layer he couldn't get into the brick-layers' union.

speaker: Yeager
words: There was a restriction.

speaker: Smith
words: Yes.

speaker: Yeager
words: I know it's beyond your time, but do you know anything at all --- Did anyone in town ever mention the Hampton Program, the Hampton Exchange Program?

speaker: Smith
words: I heard about it. From whom did I hear about it? I think I heard about it from¬∑carol; didn't I?

speaker: Wieman
words: I don't know.

speaker: Smith
words: You know her niece was here at the time and I think it was just mentioned. But that's all I know.

speaker: Yeager
words: Carol ---

speaker: Wieman
words: What year was Carol Vogt?

speaker: Smith
words: Carol Zigemeier -- Carol Vogt, yes.

speaker: Wieman
words: What year was the Hampton Exchange?

speaker: Yeager
words: It started in '46 and it went through '54 or '55. I know you were gone by then, but did you have any contact---

speaker: Smith
words: No.

speaker: Jordan
words: And, of course, by that time Collis Davis was registrar at Hampton and helped facilitate the program.

speaker: Smith
words: I'm sure that he would have been a prime instigator in such a program.

speaker: Yeager
words: Is his wife still living do you know?

speaker: Smith
words: Whose? Collis Davis's? I don't even know them.

speaker: Yeager
words: You don't even know them.

speaker: Smith
words: No, because Collis Davis wouldn't remember me because I was ---

speaker: Yeager
words: You were so young.

speaker: Smith
words: I think I was only about six or so.

speaker: Jordan
words: The students who were here in the late teens and through the twenties, did they maintain contact with your family after they left?

speaker: Smith
words: Some of them. Alphonse Henninger and Carl Saunders.

speaker: Wieman
words: Is he still living?

speaker: Smith
words: I don't know. A number of years ago when my sister was living, she came to Chicago and he was an engineer for the city water department.

speaker: Yeager
words: In Chicago?

speaker: Smith
words: In Chicago. But, see, he would be way up in his seventies now, so

speaker: Jordan
words: Well, we noticed that three of the earliest black graduates went on to Harvard about this time. I've written to Harvard to try to get more information on them but ---

speaker: Smith
words: Who are they?

speaker: Jordan
words: Collis Davis, Alphonse Henningburg went to Harvard didn't he?

speaker: Yeager
words: Leo Welker.

speaker: Smith
words: Who?

speaker: Jordan
words: Leo Welker.

speaker: Smith
words: He's one of the names I don't know because he probably was one of the ones who didn't come to the house.

speaker: Yeager
words: 1903. Class of '03.

speaker: Jordan
words: He was the first and then James Redmon about 1909 to 13.

speaker: Yeager
words: Hosea Booker Campbell. Do you know anything about him?

speaker: Smith
words: Yeah. He was very strange when he was here. I thought he would lose his mind. Is he all right now?

speaker: Yeager
words: We don't know if he's even living.

speaker: Smith
words: Well, because he was very --- we thought he was --- but he may have been a very brilliant person and he was just peculiar, but he was very odd. You know, if a child notices that you're odd, then you really do act peculiar.

speaker: Jordan
words: In what ways?

speaker: Smith
words: Well, his mannerisms and the way he acted, I thought was funny. I don't know what he did. It was something. I know he had a tic. So that was a nervous mannerism and that was something that a child would notice.

speaker: Yeager
words: Yeah. But you don't have any idea whether he's living or dead.

speaker: Smith
words: No.

speaker: Yeager
words: Do you know where he was from?

speaker: Smith
words: No. I don't have any idea where any of them were from.

speaker: Yeager
words: We had a conflict on him because it said that he was from Chicago.

speaker: Smith
words: I don't think he was.

speaker: Yeager
words: He was originally from the South?

speaker: Smith
words: I think so. You know, at one time it was considered to be --- you just wouldn't say that you were from the South. You'd say you were from some big city rather than say that you were originally from the South. And if you talk to many Negroes now, even though they are from the South, they don't say they're from the South. They say they're from some big city.

speaker: Yeager
words: You talked about a scholarship that you got from the Ladies' Educational Society.

speaker: Smith
words: Yes. That paid for my graduation. And I was to pay it back. And which I did at twenty-five dollars a month. I made seventy-five. I paid the Ladies' Aid twenty-five dollars every month, or whatever, the Ladies' Society.

speaker: Yeager
words: How was that scholarship arranged?

speaker: Smith
words: You applied for it. And they knew that I couldn't graduate unless I had the money. And they gave it to me.

speaker: Jordan
words: What were the expenses? Diploma? Cap and gown?

speaker: Smith
words: For the cap and gown and your sheepskin. I think it was $125.00 and that was a lot of money back in those days.

speaker: Wieman
words: That was a semester's tuition too in those days.

speaker: Smith
words: Yes, so you see that was a lot of money. And that was the nicest piece of paper I ever received when they sent that back to me that it was paid.

speaker: Yeager
words: Is Hilda C,odfrey living?

speaker: Smith
words: Yes she is. She lives in Ottumwa. And her name is Hilda Wilson. You know, she worked at the college. In the college library.

speaker: Yeager
words: And that's whom you visited in the library when you were young?

speaker: Smith
words: Oh, yes. I visited her every ev.ening after we'd walk home together because she lived on Spring Street and I lived on. First Ave. She lived one block south of the light and I lived one block west of the light.

speaker: Yeager
words: The housing wasn't segregated in any way here in Grinnell, was it?

speaker: Smith
words: No.

speaker: Yeager
words: It wasn't at all.

speaker: Smith
words: Well, now that I don't know. Oscar and Addie, they bought a house on ---

speaker: Wieman
words: Tenth Avenue and Summer Street. And the Lucases lived first on north West.

speaker: Smith
words: Yes. And the reason they moved from north West to 511 Second Avenue was because Momma bought the house at 411 First Avenue. You see the house at 511 had been given to Mother by Mumford. My mother had taken care of Mumford. Mumford was an old drayer and he told her that if she would take care of him until he died, she could have the house.

speaker: Yeager
words: In the tape it seemed that there were quite a few people who lived in like a --- on the same street, next to each other.

speaker: Smith
words: Well, that was because the three sisters lived within three blocks.

speaker: Yeager
words: That was just coincidence?

speaker: Smith
words: That was just coincidence. I think the man's name was who wanted Mother to have the house at 411 and so he was instrumental in seeing that she got that house. Because 511 was much smaller and with six children it wasn't big enough.

speaker: Wieman
words: Going back to housing, the Tibbses lived over on Elm Street and where did Mrs. Redrick live?

speaker: Smith
words: Redrick lived on Center Street right by the railroad tracks.

speaker: Wieman
words: Oh, yeah. Kind of in the neighborhood. Closer to your neighborhood, but not really in it.

speaker: Smith
words: Not really.

speaker: Wieman
words: I'm trying to think of where some of the other people lived.

speaker: Smith
words: Mrs. Jones lived way down by where Harley Harrington lived, on Broad Street, way south, down by the dump.

speaker: Yeager
words: Who was Mrs. Jones?

speaker: Smith
words: She was just a Negro who lived here.

speaker: Yeager
words: You don't know anything about her?

speaker: Smith
words: I don't know one thing. I don't even know where she worked. I know she must have maybe she didn't work. I don't know, but I know she lived by the ---

speaker: Yeager
words: She wasn't related to anyone?

speaker: Smith
words: No. She lived down by the dump. That's where the city dump used to be down there. I don't even know where it was because we weren't allowed to go that way.

speaker: Wieman
words: She musn't have been the kind of person you would associate with.

speaker: Smith
words: Well Paul and I always said she was a witch.

speaker: Wieman
words: She's the one you called the witch.

speaker: Smith
words: Yeah. And of course we were always scared of Mrs. Redrick's daughter-in-law because she always tied a rag on her heA(' and went down the railroad tracks. You know how kids are.

speaker: Yeager
words: It seems like you mentioned that the Redricks were related to the Tibbs.

speaker: Smith
words: They are. Mayme Redrick became Mavme Tibbs. So that was her daughter. And there was an Edith Redrick, a Robert Redrick, a Mayme Redricls".. Robert Redrick lived right next to the railroad track and his mother lived in the next house. Mother had known Mrs. Redrick before because her name was Miss Brown.

speaker: Yeager
words: Whose name was Miss Brown?

speaker: Smith
words: Redrick. Mrs. Redrick.

speaker: Yeager
words: Before she was married?

speaker: Smith
words: Yes. Mrs. Redrick. That was the mother of Mayme and Bob and Edith.

speaker: Yeager
words: Now your family had little contact with the Redricks?

speaker: Smith
words: Very little. Mother was very conscious of social strata and she said that she heard that Mrs. Redrick tied her children up by their thumbs and whipped them so that put them ---

speaker: Jordan
words: On a lower level.

speaker: Smith
words: Yes. So she said she wouldn't have anything to do with any of them. And then she always kept all of ber blinds closed.

speaker: Yeager
words: She wasn't very friendly then or ---

speaker: Smith
words: It wasn't that but she was just peculiar and if you ever asked her a question, she'd say,"Oh, over on River to River Road."So, if anybody ever said anything about, tell us about,"Oh, over on River to River Road."That's if you don't want them to know."Over on River to River Road."

speaker: Wieman
words: That's Highway 6, River to River Road.

speaker: Yeager
words: Were there a lot --- I was told by someone that when the highways were being built When were the highways built in Grinnell? Do you have any idea?

speaker: Smith
words: Well, they had a lot of paving men who came here. And then Mr. Spencer put in the concrete sidewalks in Grinnell. He was a Negro. And you'll see his name down.

speaker: Wieman
words: Yeah, that's right.

speaker: Yeager
words: Who was Mr. Spencer?

speaker: Wieman
words: He was sent here to do that job?

speaker: Smith
words: Yes.

speaker: Yeager
words: He lived here in Grinnell?

speaker: Smith
words: No. He came in to put in the sidewalks. I don't know how many --- a lot of sidewalks. And if you look down you see the little

speaker: Wieman
words: Inscription.

speaker: Yeager
words: What year was this in?

speaker: Smith
words: Oh, well, it was before I was born. I wouldn't know. Well, it might not have been before I was born

speaker: Wieman
words: Well, the sidewalks were probably put in in the late 1890's or early 1900' s. I can remember a few wo0.d-planked roads and I can remember when the streets were paved.

speaker: Smith
words: And then they had the paving gangs that came in.

speaker: Wieman
words: Were they black?

speaker: Smith
words: Yes . ¬∑ And they stayed with Aunt P,nn Le.

speaker: Wieman
words: They did?

speaker: Smith
words: Yes.

speaker: Yeager
words: Aunt Annie ?

speaker: Smith
words: Good .. , Brown.

speaker: Yeager
words: She was the

speaker: Smith
words: She was the transformation lady.

speaker: Yeager
words: Frank Field you mentioned on the tape.

speaker: Smith
words: That was one of Aunt Annie's husbands.

speaker: Yeager
words: Oh. O.K.

speaker: Smith
words: The one that's in jail. That was in jail.

speaker: Yeager
words: And you called him the bum, didn't you?

speaker: Wieman
words: Aunt Annie had a colorful life, didn't she?

speaker: Smith
words: Oh, didn't she? I'll tell you.

speaker: Yeager
words: Anything about the Tibbs family? Do you have contact with that family?

speaker: Smith
words: No. I went to Marshalltown Sunday and visited a friend there and she said that one of the Tibbs girls, Roberta, lives there and she had four children.

speaker: Yeager
words: That's in Montezuma?

speaker: Jordan
words: Marshalltown.

speaker: Smith
words: There's nobody in Montezuma.

speaker: Wieman
words: Did you know the people at Morrow Chapel in Marshalltown?

speaker: Smith
words: The only people I know --- Anna May was married to Harry Gilmore and he was from Marshalltown. And this Mr. and Mrs. Johnson that we go to visit in Marshalltown were very good friends of the Gilmores. And so that's the only reason I know them.

speaker: Yeager
words: Can you tell me something about the Kiners?

speaker: Smith
words: The Kiners are --- Lena Lucas is Mrs. Kiner's half-sister. Lena Lucas' mother was Clara Lucas and then she was Clara Western. When she became Clara Western, she had Alma Western. And Alma Western became Alma Kiner. Now, Lena Lucas had a quarter of the section.

speaker: Yeager
words: Was she John Lucas'

speaker: Smith
words: Niece.

speaker: Yeager
words: Niece. O.K.

speaker: Smith
words: She was Theodore Lucas' daughter. And, see, she's the one --That's the last piece of property that belonged to Henry Lucas. Now that piece of property has gone to her son, Theodore Benning. She died in September at ninety-four.

speaker: Yeager
words: Oh.

speaker: Smith
words: So Alma is her half-sister. So that's what see, from the Lucases --- John Lucas was Lena's uncle and that was my uncle too.

speaker: Yeager
words: Oh, I see. And so you go down there every so often and visit.

speaker: Smith
words: Well, see, if we didn't go there to visit, we'd stay in a motel because I still have a house here. And so, we have to come to see about it.

speaker: Yeager
words: Do you have any plans of ever settling back in Grinnell.

speaker: Smith
words: No, not yet. But you never know. My daughter told me the other day, she said,"Well, Daddy has to go out there to see about the house so much, you ought to move in that house and let me move in your house."

speaker: Yeager
words: Has Grinnell changed a lot since you ---

speaker: Smith
words: Oh, I should say. It's so much bigger.

speaker: Wieman
words: Gosh, yes. It was two miles square when you were growing up.
